description:
Anabas testudineus, commonly known as the climbing perch or walking catfish, is a freshwater fish species belonging to the family Anabantidae. It is native to Southeast Asia, including countries such as India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia.

The Anabas testudineus is a unique fish species known for its ability to breathe atmospheric air and survive out of water for extended periods. This is made possible by a specialized respiratory organ called the labyrinth organ, which allows the fish to extract oxygen from the air. This adaptation enables the climbing perch to move across land and even climb up trees or damp surfaces in search of new water sources or to escape unfavorable conditions.

The fish has a rounded, elongated body with a large mouth and small, spiny scales. It typically ranges in color from dark brown to olive green, with a pale underbelly. The climbing perch is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, small invertebrates, and even small fish.

Anabas testudineus is known for its resilience and ability to thrive in diverse aquatic environments, including stagnant ponds, swamps, and rice fields. It is an important food source for local communities in its native range and is also commercially farmed in some regions.
